item.title: Zhongning Industry
item.description: Like much of Inner Mongolia, Zhongning County is growing rapidly. Most of the buildings in this industrial complex, nestled between the Yellow River and the Tengger Desert, were built after 2010.

item.title: Ivanpah Solar Electric Generating System
item.description: Instead of using solar cells to directly convert sunlight into electricity, the Ivanpah Solar Electric Generating System uses thousands of mirrors to focus sunlight on a boiler held 459 feet above the Mojave Desert. The resulting superheated steam drives conventional turbines to create electricity.

item.title: Northern Tbilisi
item.description: Tbilisi is the capital of Georgia, a former Soviet Republic along the southern margin of the Caucasus Mountains. The Mtkvari River flows from north to south through the city, on its way from Turkey to the Caspian Sea. On the outskirts of this now vibrant city, abandoned factories, relics from the Soviet era, line the river banks.

item.title: Captiva Pass
item.description: Florida’s Gulf Coast features a complex, evolving underwater landscape. Natural-color satellite imagery is capable of mapping the sea floor in shallow water, and timely data could be used to revise nautical charts in the wake of hurricanes or other intense storms.

item.title: Western Beijing
item.description: In 2013 the population of Beijing reached 21.15 million, an increase of 455,000 from the year before—roughly the current population of Kansas City, Missouri. To accommodate the influx of new residents, high-rises (accentuated by long shadows in this Planet Labs image) are perpetually under construction.

item.title: Gobi Desert Road
item.description: This ruler-straight line is the trace of a dirt road in the barren expanse of Inner Mongolia. The bright red color is likely from soil exposed by the removal of desert pavement—a thin layer of dark rocks that forms in areas where winds or other forces carry away dust and sand.

item.title: Star Dunes
item.description: These complex star dunes, with multiple arms radiating out from a central peak, were sculpted by the shifting winds of western Algeria.

item.title: North Antelope Rochelle Mine
item.description: Forty percent of the coal mined in the United States comes from the Powder River Basin in Wyoming. The North Antelope Rochelle Mine, pictured here, is both the largest in the basin, and the largest in the United States. Since the mine opened in 1983 it has produced over 1.8 billion tons of coal.

item.title: Desert Infrastructure, Keriya
item.description: In the expanses of western China new infrastructure—highways, factories, even entire cities—appear seemingly overnight. Satellite images indicate construction of these facilities on the southern edge of the Taklamakan Desert began sometime in 2010, and continues today.

item.title: Amber Highway
item.description: Poland’s Amber Highway (Autostrada Bursztynowa) is currently under construction near the village of Nowosolna (left) and Las Wiączyński forest (center). When completed, it will link the Baltic coast of Poland to the Czech Republic.

item.title: Agriculture on the Shores of Issyk Kul
item.description: These long, thin fields are sandwiched between the Küngöy Ala-Too Mountains and Lake Issyk Kul. Because Issyk Kul is in a closed basin (water that enters the lake leaves only by evaporation), the water is slightly salty.

item.title: Shiprock
item.description: Ship Rock is the remnant of an ancient volcano that now towers above the New Mexico desert. The central spire (the main vent of the volcanic system) is accompanied by 3 prominent dikes (vertical sheets of solidified magma) arranged like the spokes of a wheel.

item.title: Winslow
item.description: The winding Little Colorado River just east of Winslow, Arizona supports a narrow band of green vegetation along its banks. The river itself was filled with red-brown sediment on October 10, 2014, the day after heavy rains fell upstream.

item.title: Circular Fields
item.description: Farmers in the Fertile Crescent have relied on irrigation since the dawn of agriculture. Water from reservoirs developed on the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers in the past 25 years enabled the expansion of cropland in the region, including these circular fields in the Şanlıurfa Province of southeastern Turkey.

item.title: The Mississippi River & New Orleans
item.description: The mighty Mississippi River runs through the center of New Orleans, Louisiana. While the river is the lifeblood of New Orleans—providing access to the interior of North America from the Gulf of Mexico—it is also a threat. A system of levees along the river protects the center of the city from flooding and hurricane storm surges.

item.title: Wadi Dib Ring Complex
item.description: It may look like an impact crater, but instead of being the scar from an incoming meteorite, the Wadi Dib ring complex came from within the Earth itself. The circular structure is the result of an upwelling of magma that solidified into a series of different rock types, each with a distinct color.

item.title: Comondú-La Purísima Volcanic Field
item.description: Mexico’s Baja California is home to several clusters of volcanoes, including the Comondú-La Purísima volcanic field. Eruptions in the area began about 11 million years ago, and the most recent may have occurred within the past 12,000 years.

item.title: Longyangxia Dam Solar Park
item.description: Blue squares in an otherwise empty desert demarcate one of the world’s largest solar power plants. The solar portion of the Longyangxia hydro-solar project, located in China’s Qinghai Province, generates up to 320 Megawatts of power. Construction took only 9 months, from its start in March 2013 to testing in December.

item.title: Chichibu-shi
item.description: Chichibu-shi, Japan (about 50 miles northwest of Tokyo) consists of a mixture of urban, industrial, and natural landscapes. The city is at the top of the image, with a limestone quarry just below. A reservoir and forested mountains fill the bottom of the image.

item.title: Anti Atlas Mountains
item.description: This picture of the eastern margin of the Anti-Atlas Mountains reveals complex drainage patterns superimposed on a colorful, rocky landscape. In vegetation-free areas satellite images can provide an important resource for mapping geology.

item.title: Ansi River
item.description: The Ansi River, in Jammu and Kashmir, flows into the Chenab River, a major tributary of the Indus River. The Ansi is an example of a braided river, with many small channels that split and rejoin along the river course.

item.title: Nan Shan Mountains
item.description: The deep valleys and sharp ridges of the Nan Shan range in central China are highlighted in this early-morning satellite image. Many of Planet Labs’ doves were launched from the International Space Station and remain in a similar orbit, which allows observations at different times of day.

item.title: Ocotillo Wind Project
item.description: The 80-meter-tall turbines of the Ocotillo Wind project cast long shadows across the Imperial Valley’s desert floor on the morning of September 22, 2014. Each of the 112 turbines is capable of generating 2.37 megawatts of power, for a maximum output of 265 megawatts.

item.title: Fall Colors
item.description: Vivid red maples stand out against the dark green evergreen forest and brown scrub landscape of the Pleasantview Hills. In this region of southern Idaho forests grow mainly on north-facing slopes and stream valleys, where they are sheltered during the hot and dry summers.

item.title: Alborz Mountains
item.description: Small villages, fields, orchards, and pastures are scattered across the hilly terrain of the Alborz Mountains in southern Gilan Province, Iran.

item.title: Flooding on Mormon Mesa
item.description: In the wake of heavy rains on September 8, 2014, water filled depressions and (usually) dry washes on Mormon Mesa in eastern Nevada. Standing water is visible on the mesa in a Planet Labs image collected on September 9, 2014, compared to a USGS/NASA Landsat image from August 22, 2014.

item.title: Muyezersky, Republic of Karelia
item.description: Muyezersky (also spelled Muezerskiy) is a logging town in northwest Russia, near the border with Finland. A railroad, visible running vertically through the center of town, links Muyezersky to Baltic Sea ports.

item.title: Hudson River
item.description: Skyscrapers on both sides of the Hudson River cast long shadows in this picture captured by a Planet Labs satellite on the morning of September 7, 2014. Boat wakes reveal that most traffic is traveling north/south along the river, with the exception of a ferry running between the Paulus Hook (New Jersey) and World Financial Center (New York) terminals.

item.title: Otog, Inner Mongolia
item.description: In this image of Otog, Inner Mongolia, China, there appears to be a large area covered by greenhouses in the northeast, and an evaporate mine in the east.

item.title: Sequoia National Park
item.description: In the Sequoia National Park mountains southeast of Fresno and northeast of Bakersfield, you can see the clear treeline near the ridgetop.

item.title: Lake Diefenbaker, Saskatchewan
item.description: Filled in 1967, Lake Diefenbaker is a 140-mile-long reservoir along the South Saskatchewan and Qu’Appelle Rivers. Diefenbaker is renowned for harboring extremely large fish: the world record rainbow trout (48 pounds) and burbot (25 pounds) were both caught in the lake.

item.title: Adeii Eechii Cliffs
item.description: The prominent Adeii Eechii Cliffs form the southwestern boundary of the Moenkopi Plateau. Strong winds from the southwest dominate during the dry season, sculpting sand into light-colored dunes that stretch from the edge of the cliffs towards the upper right of this image.

item.title: Dulles International Airport
item.description: In this image of part of Dulles airport in Washington, DC, you can see the main terminal, concourses, runways, airplanes on the tarmac, and traveller parking lots. It is the busiest airport in the Washington metropolitan area, with over 22 million passengers a year. (The image is rotated with north towards the upper right.)

item.title: Boise
item.description: The Boise River snakes through suburban Boise, with baseball fields along its bank. The city crawls up the Boise foothills to the northeast.

item.title: Alvord Hot Springs
item.description: The Alvord Hot Springs form a tiny oasis in eastern Oregon. Water from the springs spills out onto the Alvord Desert, where it evaporates, staining the dry lake bed.

item.title: Northgate Hub
item.description: Starting in early fall of 2014, farmers in Saskatchewan, Canada will be able to ship their crops by rail to the United States through a new grain handling and shipping facility. These satellite images show progress on the construction of the Northgate Hub between September 10, 2013 (Landsat 8, NASA/USGS), and August 28, 2014 (Planet Labs).

item.title: Scarborough, Ontario
item.description: In this urban shot of Scarborough, Ontario, Canada, you can see the Canadian Pacific Railway Toronto Yard in the top center, and the Tam O’shanter Golf Club on the left.

item.title: Hawthorne Army Depot
item.description: A rectangular grid of roads links evenly-spaced bunkers at the Hawthorne Army Depot. The depot, located in western Nevada, stores and decommissions conventional weaponry for the U.S. military.

item.title: Irrigated Fields
item.description: Dark green fields stand out against the pale desert floor in Pinal County, Arizona. The region’s farms rely on irrigation, since they receive less than 10 inches of rain a year. Irrigation water comes from two main sources: the Colorado River and aquifers.

item.title: Grand Canyon
item.description: The red, sediment-filled Colorado River contrasts with blue-green Havasu Creek in the heart of Grand Canyon National Park. The Colorado River is almost always red in spring and summer, since it collects silt from a huge watershed. Short tributaries, however, usually run clear—only picking up significant sediment during flash floods.

item.title: Wuzhong, Ningxia
item.description: Wuzhong is a rapidly-growing city located in north-central China. The dense urban core is surrounded by fields, likely rice paddies. Irrigation water is brought to the otherwise arid region by the sediment-filled Yellow River, to the northwest (above and left) of the city.

item.title: Bohai Sea Aquaculture
item.description: Rectangular ponds along the coast of China’s Bohai Sea indicate the presence of aquaculture. Species farmed in the area include shrimp, sea cucumber, and abalone. The inland landscape is also intensively farmed, featuring small villages surrounded by fields.

item.title: Burning Fields, Itumbiara
item.description: In this August 9th Planet Labs image, a large field is burning. Landsat 8 observed the same location, near Itumbiara, Brazil, just a day before. This shows the field before burning, and also reveal areas that appear to have been tilled that day, after earlier burns (visible below the active fire).

item.title: Cambridge
item.description: In this shot outside of Cambridge, Ohio, we see a mix of fields and forested land on either side of Ohio State Route 170. Ohio’s main agricultural products by land area and value are corn, soybeans, and hay.

item.title: Iron Mine, vicinity of Belo Horizonte, Minas Gerais
item.description: This dramatic image was taken of an iron mine outside of Belo Horizonte, Brazil — in addition to seeing into the mine, the lake runs orange. Brazil is the world’s 3rd largest producer of iron ore after China and Australia.

item.title: Castaic Reservoir
item.description: The shoreline of Castaic Lake, a reservoir northwest of Los Angeles, hints at the extent of California’s ongoing drought. As of August 5, 2014, the reservoir was only 46 percent full, compared to the historical average of 55 percent.

item.title: North of Bakersfield
item.description: In this image of agricultural fields north of Bakersfield, there is a stark contrast between the irrigated fields and the adjacent ravine-ridden desert. Bakersfield has been the hardest-hit large urban area by the current drought.

item.title: Arkhangelsk, Arkhangelsk Oblast
item.description: Here we can see the center of Arkhangelsk, a Russian city at the top of the Northern Dvina River delta, which flows into the nearby White Sea.

item.title: Mississisippi River, Tennessee and Arkansas Border
item.description: In this image of the Mississippi River with Tennessee on the east bank, and Arkansas on the west, you can see a boat heading south. The winding stream to the east is the Hatchie River — as the only major stream of West Tennessee that has never been majorly modified by human activity, its environs are indicative of what the area likely resembled prior to the 19th century.

item.title: Três Marias Reservoir, Minas Gerais
item.description: The Represa Três Marias, the result of damming the São Francisco river, is one of the largest reservoirs in Brazil. In 2014, Minas Gerais experienced one of the worst droughts of the last 50 years. The lower water level can be seen by using the compare tool.

item.title: Coal Mines, Shanxi Province
item.description: The town of Jingping is surrounded by a few large coal mines. China is the largest coal producer in the world, and Shanxi Province contains most of China’s easily accessible coal, producing more than 300 million metric tonnes annually.

item.title: Paracatu River, Minas Gerais
item.description: The Paracatu river winds through the state of Minas Gerais, providing irrigation for crops in the Brasilândia de Minas municipality. The primary agricultural products for the region include soybeans, corn, manioc, beans and rice.

item.title: Walla Walla County
item.description: Just south of the confluence of the Snake and Columbia rivers, the McNary National Wildlife Refuge is home to one of the highest concentrations of waterfowl in North America. It covers the marshy area to the left and most of the river at the top of the image, surrounding the fields of rural Burbank.

item.title: Pielinen Lake, North Karelia
item.description: Pielinen Lake is the fourth largest in Finland. The dark water color is attributed to humic substances that drain into the lake. This image is just north of Koli, one of Finland’s 37 national parks.

item.title: Evaporate Mine, Inner Mongolia
item.description: The basin of Baga Nur, a former salt lake south of Ordos in Inner Mongolia, is mined for salt. Inner Mongolia is rich in rare earth resources and mineral deposits, so many evaporate mines like the one pictured have been built.

item.title: Yellow River, Henan Province
item.description: This dam on the Yellow River, just downstream from the Xiaolangdi Dam in Mengjin, China, suffers from mud and sand build up. This build up causes the river bed to rise and slow the water flow. Every year, there is a sand-washing operation to clear out the deposits and wash mud and sand into the sea.

item.title: Airport, Beijing
item.description: Beijing Capital International Airport Terminal 3 was built for the 2008 Olympic Games, and is now the second largest airport terminal in the world. The airport itself is an exclave of the Chaoyang District, but the area surrounding it is the suburban Shunyi district.

item.title: St. Catharines, Ontario
item.description: This coastline on Lake Ontario stretches from the western side of St. Catharines, the largest city in the Niagara region of Ontario, Canada. The Queen Elizabeth Way runs right by the water, heading to Toronto.

item.title: San Francisco Bay Area
item.description: The southernmost portion of the San Francisco Bay contains a number of salt ponds and levee trails. Cutting through several nature reserves, the Dumbarton bridge connects East Palo Alto and Fremont. Facebook’s campus can be seen in the lower left.

item.title: Sabina Fire
item.description: We captured this image of the Sabina wildfire, in Riverside County, just 10 minutes after it was reported on July 23. From the photo, you can see the fire’s size, the path it had burned through, the wind direction, and of course its exact location. This timely and accurate information is essential for wildfire teams in safely containing a blaze.

item.title: Indian Valley Reservoir
item.description: The effects of California’s drought become quite apparent in this image of a reservoir in Lake County, which supplies water to nearby Yolo County. In a non-drought year the visible water covers roughly twice the area, and contains ten times the volume.

item.title: Han River, Hubei Province
item.description: A new bridge crosses the Han River near Yangxipu in Hubei Province, China. Road construction is still in progress, reflecting the rapid pace of development seen elsewhere in this image - new roads, buildings, and changes in land use are seen throughout.

item.title: Istinden Mountain, Troms County
item.description: A snow-dappled landscape surrounds Istinden Mountain in Norway, near Malselv. Norway’s main north-south roadway E6 runs through the top left corner. Lake Vesltindvatnet, which is covered in snow, is also visible.

item.title: Onega River Delta
item.description: On July 19, 2014 a Planet Labs satellite captured this image of exposed mud flats along the southeastern shore of Russia’s Onega Bay.

item.title: Desertification Control Project, Ningxia
item.description: Agricultural lands abut the Yellow River, just outside of Touzha in Pingluo County, China. This is part of the Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region in Northwestern China, where a desertification control project is under way to preserve agricultural lands.

item.title: Afsin-Elbistan Power Complex, Kahramanmaraş
item.description: Afsin-Elbistan A, part of the 2.8 GW Afsin-Elbistan power complex, which represents about 5% of Turkey’s generation capacity. To the right is an open pit coal mine, and just southwest is the Collolar coalfield. This region has about 50% of Turkey’s lignite coal reserves.

item.title: Diyarbakir, Southeastern Anatolia
item.description: This image captures agricultural lands along the Tigris River, and Diyarbakir’s famous walls, which ring the old city. Made out of basalt, the walls were built during the Byzantine Empire. Recently completed additions to the Diyarbakir Airport are also visible.

item.title: São José da Barra, Minas Gerais
item.description: Just east of the Furnas Dam in Minas Gerais state of Brazil, this image shows where the Rio Grande would meet the Rio Sapucai. The dam was built for electricity generation, and created this reservoir which is now used for a variety of recreational activities like water skiing and fishing.

item.title: Suez Canal, Ismailia
item.description: Ships head north through the Suez Canal, passing by Izbat Abu Sitayt between Lake Timsah to the north, and Great Bitter Lake to the south. The Isamilia Canal, or Sweet Water Canal, runs parallel to the Suez Canal and supplies water to the surrounding regions.

item.title: Great Bitter Lake, Ismailia
item.description: Ships pass one another in Great Bitter Lake, midway through the Suez Canal in Egypt. The Great Bitter Lake is one of two places along the 193.3km long Suez Canal where ships can pass each other.

item.title: Patrocínio, Minas Gerais
item.description: Cattle and soybeans are the main economic activities in Patrocínio, in the Paranaíba River basin. It is part of the Cerrado, a tropical savanna biome that extends through the states of Goiás and Minas Gerais in Brazil. The World Wide Fund for Nature named it the most biologically rich savanna in the world.

item.title: Ulanqab, Inner Mongolia
item.description: Rapid development of the area around Qitai town in Shangdu County, Ulanqab, is evident from the changing land use: New buildings, farms, and expansion of blue roofs near the pond, which house livestock.
